captions.text: Alright, fine, for fuck's sake, I'll review Borderlands if it'll make you shut up.
Except it won't, will it?
We both know nothing could do that short of surgically removing your fucking jaw, and
even then you can still drool down my ear.
I've been here too many times before, I delay reviewing a game and all the fans of the game
I feel the only possible explanation is that I'm struck dumb by how good it is, but they
nagged me to review it anyway in order to confirm their feelings and level up their
internet cocks.
And then of course I piddle all over it in an act that you'd think would come as no surprise
to anyone with the slightest grasp of pattern recognition and a wounded denial-ridden nerd
mob leave hate comments suggesting that I must have misinterpreted my own opinion.
Well I need another week to play the two dicks gelatinous cube that is Mass Effect 2, so
here we go again.
I wish more developers would be as considerate as the Dark Void team and just stop making
the game halfway through.
The reason why I've been putting it off is because I'm well aware that Borderlands
Super admit you Finns are mistakes BORDERLANDS is a single FPS RPG in which
You play one, and just one, of four mercenaries who have come to the planet Pandora, which
looks like what would happen if the cast of Mad Max and the Dukes of Hazzard intermarried
then colonised the Middle East with an invading force of garbage trucks.
You're there in search of something called the Vault, which is either a legendary bonanza,
a myth orchestrated by the Planetary Tourist Board, or a big fat MacGuffin to drive what
little plot there is.
The story aspect doesn't so much as take a back seat as it does get tied up with jump
leads and dumped in the boot of a completely different car.
Those characters, while just trying to repurpose your pelvis as a shoe tree, will only talk
to you when they have sidequests, and even then only in the form of a paragraph on an
impersonal briefing screen.
It's one of those games that seem like all the actual drama is going on whenever you're
not around, I guess because it'd be hard to fit into your busy schedule of shooting
the same four or five guys in the face fifty thousand times. Whatever, it's the odd memorbiga
setup, all those girly things like story and words are all just a framework for the missions,

or perhaps I should say the mission The mission is to go into a scrapyard and shoot Jason Voorhees Never before has cover art been so indicative of a game content because that literally all you do Sometimes it just for the killing itself sometimes it because Jason
has stolen something you want to get back. Occasionally the mission is to shoot Jason's
dog or his pet killer space lobsters but there'll probably be a few Jasons hanging out on the
way. It's like all the mission providers have bought shares in the local hockey mask
factory. I suppose this is geared to the memorbiger crowd, who are well known for putting up with
all the samey grind in the world if it means they get experience points and fancy weapons
with blue names at the end of it. I've had a great idea for a game these people would
I might as well mention that there's vehicle driving for swiftly getting from one Jason-infested
scrapyard to another, vehicles which handle like a fat dog on a space hopper and are about
as sturdy and well-armoured as an egg and crisp sandwich, but what I really want to
talk about is the GUI.
It's been a while since I've seen in-game menus as bad as these, it's like PowerPoint
threw up on a Cluedo board and died.
You're constantly switching out weapons for slightly better models, like a militant
germaphobe, which is par for the course.
The little window showing the stats of your current weapon appearing when you hover over
I really like how Blizzardets can be messier in time, so the gelmi≈ü normal fight in kampanions
does matter.
The Zippered T –ø—Ä–∏–∑ üç£It's fantastic, though,' streamers often say.
But what is this, how could...
Press 1-2 on the Mom's payment?
Oh, the combat mode function.
Unless it's really that great.

Oh Maybe The The Ancenter FHHHHM tracking button here stops the attack properly The integrated mechanic is elegant and or even isn better but I like it it just as good as the results I think this character is specifically designed to be annoying in which case I not sure
The developers should be congratulated for doing their job so well, and tactfully reminded
that deliberately annoying is still annoying.
At the end of it all, Borderlands is well presented, but get under the sheen of polish,
it's just a dull, sparse, nuts and bolts shooter with some unnecessarily Good Writing bridging
the slow process of watching numbers steadily increase.
A game for the kind of person who takes photos of his car's odometer whenever it clocks another
thousand miles.
And it might be true that it becomes tolerable if you do it with some friends around, but
so is dying of bowel cancer, and that way they might even feel obliged to take you skydiving.
